loans.name: Percida's Group

texts.en:
Percida C. is from the village of Mansabay Bajo,Lopez Jaena. She is 41 years old. Percida is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Percida is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Percida owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks in the local communiy. Percida has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Percida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Percida C. group is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Percida from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Hermocilla

texts.en:
Hermocilla is a married woman who lives in Arbor, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store and a vehicle transport business. Her husband Leonardo, who is 43 years old, works as a taxi driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 14 and 20 years old. Hermocilla joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hermocilla has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 24,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,800, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing PHP 24,000, which she intends to use to buy stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of children. Hermocilla is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Mr. Edgar R. is from the village of Tabid, Misamis Occidental. He is 61 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. Edgar has owned and operated a piggery business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In January 2011, Edgar joined PMPC under the pension loan program to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edgar is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials to construct a piggery. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs and in saving for future use, loan repayments and possible business expansions.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh lò bánh mì. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase tools and other equipment to expand the business

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer C. is a 28-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: motorcycle transport, meat vending and a computer games business. She lives in Samboan, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her motorcycle transport, meat vending and computer games businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,500. Jennifer is now borrowing PHP 15,500 to fund operations. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Jennifer aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To fund the operations of her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima's Group

texts.en:
G. Fatima lives in Jaranwala, a small city in the Punjab region of Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a two-room brick house for more than 20 years. G. Fatima is a housewife; she stays at home and does her household work. In her spare time, she also supports her husband by taking care of his buffaloes. G. Fatima has 3 daughters and 5 sons. Her 2 eldest sons work in a factory for a small salary. Three of the remaining children are in school while the others stay at home.

G. Fatima has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, for her husband, who operates a dairy business in the community. He will use the loan to buy another buffalo to produce more milk and to sell to many more customers. He started this business 5 years ago and is now getting good at it. G. Fatima is hopeful that by purchasing another buffalo, her husband’s business will expand and he will be able to increase his clients and profit. G. Fatima is a regular lender with Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan years, she established good credit behavior and never missed a meeting.

Note: In the photo, G. Fatima is holding a book (the Asasah Passbook).

loans.use: to buy another buffalo

loans.name: Mahdi

texts.en:
Mahdi is a 37-year-old married man, father of four kids, living in Bint Jbeil and working in construction for18 years. Mahdi is specialized in painting walls in addition to decorative plates. In order to improve his work and make it more professional, Mahdi is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, to buy a special generator used in painting that helps in spreading the paint equally on the walls and the decorative plates.

 Mahdi is a talented, hard worker, who looks at his work from a professional point of view. Most of his clients are relatives, neighbors, and general contractors. He assures good client service because he believes it's his future investment. Mahdi hopes he can keep on providing secure and healthy living for his family, in addition to providing good education for his kids.

loans.use: To buy a special generator that helps in spreading the paint

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en:
Aggrey is a farmer from Kitale in western Kenya where he has been farming for five years. He is 25 years old and married. His main products are maize and beans which are sold to the local market.

He has requested a loan of 31,200Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to meet the basic needs of his family. He says that his biggest challenge has been lack of enough animal feed, especially during the dry seasons. He hopes that in the next five years he will have acquired two more dairy cows and a motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Zenzele Group

texts.en:
Hawukelaphi is 57 years old and widowed. She cares for 6 children, between the ages of 18 months and 26 years. She runs a retail business near Nkandla in Kwa Z. Natal, South Africa. In the photo she is standing on the far left in black and white.

She has been in this business for 10 years and sells vegetables and fruit. She also gets income from a government grant. She says that the main challenge to her business is that stock is expensive and when she sells on the streets, sometimes it rains.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses to buy more vegetables and fruit. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her grow her business, and make profit to support her family. In future, she would like to grow her business further and build her house.

In her comments she adds that she would like to thank WDB because now she can afford to buy stock and support her family.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fruit

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace Y. is from the village of North Mapang, Rizal. She is 46 years old. Mary Grace is a widow and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Grace owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling snacks and other delicacies to sell. She has been operating her business for 5 years and earns a monthly net income of 2300 PHP.

In 2008, Mary Grace joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Grace has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for her business. Mary Grace is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Mary Grace from PMPC.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer P. is came from the village of Sepac, Sapang Dalaga. She is 26 years old and single. Jennifer is engaged in the retail sector running a grocery store as her means of income. She has been operating her business  for two years with an income of 4000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Jennifer joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jennifer is requesting her 1st loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new stock for her store.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new stock for her store

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
Tư Nguyễn Thị (20211030064) is a 52-year-old woman living in the town of Huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Tư is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Phù Lưu 1 (Nhóm 04).


Tư is married and has 3 adult children.  To making a living, Tư operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Tư has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2007, Tư joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Tư has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,152,000 VND which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  This will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  Tư plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Huỳnh Thị T. (0) is a 54-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  Nguyễn Thị D. (0) is a 30-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her furniture-making business.


3.  Nguyễn Thị H. (0) is a 36-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Tư Nguyễn Thị (20211030064) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố huyện Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Tư là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Phù Lưu 1 (Nhóm 04).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán.  Tư thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 30 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Tư kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Tư đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Tư đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Huỳnh Thị T. (0) là 54 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Nguyễn Thị D. (0) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực sản xuất.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh chế tạo hàng nội thất.


3.  Nguyễn Thị H. (0) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Tilebaldy

texts.en:
Tilebaldy B. is 63 years old, married, and has six grown children.  Tilebaldy and his wife are pensioners. To earn additional income, they are engaged in cattle breeding and land cultivating. With initial capital of 8,000 KGS, they managed to develop a farm with three cows, ten sheep, twenty goats and three horses. In 2008, Tilebaldy took his first loan from Bai Tusum and Partners and repaid it without any delays. Now Tilebaldy has applied for 30,000 KGS for purchasing ten sheep. With the additional revenue, he plans to help his son in business. 
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase sheep.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem lives in Mianchannu which is a small city located in Punjab province, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has lived there in the area of Muhallah Rehmania with her family in a 2-room brick house for the past 20 years. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her clothes-selling business. She started this business to share the financial burden with her husband who is a driver by profession and provides transport services to his passengers. 

Naseem purchases clothes from the city of Multan which is famous for its clothes and embroidery industry and sells to her local area clients at a profit. With the loan, she will buy clothes in different varieties and in bulk quantities to fulfill customers' demand and to expand her business. 

She has given birth to 3 sons and a daughter. Her two elder sons are also associated with their father's driving profession and the remaining children are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Naseem is hopeful that an investment will bring more profits to her and her family’s financial condition will improve.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In her previous loan years, she always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting.

loans.use: To buy clothes for clothes-selling business

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 35 years old and married with four children whose ages are between one month and ten years. Three of the children are currently attending school. He has been practicing mixed farming for the last ten years and sells his maize, milk, beans and vegetables to the local market. He mainly depends on the income from farming to take care of the basic needs of his family.

He has requested a loan of 30,000Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to start poultry farming. The extra income from this loan will enable him to afford a good life for his family. He says that his major challenge has been poultry diseases which lead to losses. There is no insurance to cover poultry at the moment. He hopes that in the next five years he will have expanded his poultry farm and be able to supply eggs to all the shops within his locality.

loans.use: To start poultry farming.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Mrs. Carmelita A. is from the village of Gala, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old. Carmelita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita owns and operates flower gardening and snack vending businesses. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In February 2010, Carmelita joined PMPC under Barangay Official Livelihood Assistance (BOLA) program to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita is now requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used for additional capital in her flower gardening and snack vending. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, loan repayment, and education of her children.

 About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for flower gardening and snack vending

loans.name: Leonida's Group

texts.en:
Leonida C. is from the village of Divisoria Norte, Maddela, Quirino. She is 48 years old. Leonida is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Leonida C.".

Leonida is married and has six children. To make a living, Leonida owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Leonida has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Leonida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Leonida is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Leonida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Carreon's Group

texts.en:
Edna C. is from the village of Banadero, Ozamiz City. She is 39 years old, married and has five school-aged children. Mrs.Edna is one of PMPC's micro-entrepreneurs who prepares and processes a Filipino delicacy known as “longanisa” a meat viand which is usually served at breakfast. Edna is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Edna C.’s  Group". 


In Jan. 2010, Edna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to buy more "longanisa" ingredients for sale. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Edna from PMPC. She plans to purchase ingredients including meat for her "longanisa" processing.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients including meat for her "longanisa" (sausage) processing

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en:
Adnan is a 49-year-old single man, living in Tayouneh, owner of a household products store since 1975. He likes his work a lot, and he enjoys choosing the new products he's going to sell in his shop. As Adnan states this business is joyful, because every day you can find something new, that's why he has to stay up to date. 

Adnan's clients like to come and shop from his place, because he knows how to attract clients. Although Adnan has a problem talking, many of his clients understand him quickly because they are used to talking to him and seeing him often. 

Adnan sells plates, silver gifts, spoons, kettles, cups and many other useful household products. Adnan is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua for the second time, in order to increase his capital and to buy and register a motor cycle that's necessary for his business, since it eases transportation from/to wholesale shops. His previous loan helped a lot since he used it to buy special offers he got on special stocks, and he proved he was a good-standing borrower.

loans.use: To increase his capital and to buy and register a motorcycle

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita E., a 46-year-old married woman with seven school-aged children, is from the village of Olingan where she owns and operates a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling different kinds of goods in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.



In 2005, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, Lolita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store. This will be her 9th loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari (variety) store

loans.name: Elvis

texts.en:
Elvis T. is from the village of Sampaguita. He is 40 years old, married and has 1 school-aged child. Elvis owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Elvis has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Elvis joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvis is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Elvis from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla S. is from the village of Tipolohon, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Perla owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling vegetables such as onion springs and spices, in the local community. Perla has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Perla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perla has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Perla is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Perla from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables

loans.name: Enebish

texts.en:
Enebish is 43 years old, married and has three children, ages 13 to 23. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband works as a driver in the countryside. Her youngest daughter attends secondary school and her son attends college. Her oldest daughter works as a furniture store saleswoman. 

Enebish supports her family by operating a clothing retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. 

She first began her business in 2000 and now she has 1,600,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) in working capital and 800,000 MNT in sewing equipment. She sells clothes imported from Ereen and her handmade clothes. She usually sews clothing with regular help from her family. She is planning to purchase clothing materials and sew many coats for spring during Mongolian Lunar New Year’s holidays because she has vacation for 15 days. She is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan to purchase the clothing material.

Her business goal is to expand her business with this loan and be able to buy her own house.

loans.use: To purchase material to make clothes to sell

loans.name: Rima Group

texts.fr:
Esperance N. est une commerçante âgée de 30 ans qui habite la  commune de Rugombo de la Province de Cibitoke à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle tient un restaurant dans le centre de négoce de Rugombo depuis 3ans alors qu’elle pratiquait le commerce de produits alimentaires avant de commencer ce métier. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’au niveau de l’école primaire en 6e année. Elle  est divorcée et  mère de 2 enfants âgés de 11 pour la fille ainée et de 10 ans pour le garçon. Elle  arrive au 7e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  accroitre son capital  pour l’expansion de son restaurant en achetant de grandes quantités d’articles de consommation à revendre à ses clients et ainsi pouvoir accroitre ses économies. Elle espère qu’avec les économies réalisées avec ce credit, elle  sera à mesure de subvenir aux besoins familiaux et pouvoir construire sa propre maison

Elle est membre  du groupe  Communautaire« Rima».
texts.en: Esperance N. is a 30 year old businesswoman who lives in the village of Rugombo in the Cibitoke Province in western Burundi.  She has been managing a restaurant in the commercial district of Rugombo for 3 years.  Before the restaurant, she was in the business of selling basic food items.  She studied until 6th grade.  She is divorced and the mother of a daughter who is 11 years old and a boy who is 10 years old.  She is in her seventh round of community borrowing with the Turame group.  She is asking for the Kiva loan to increase the business' capital for the expansion of the restaurant by purchasing large quantities of food items to sell to its clients and to also increase their ability to save money.  She hopes that with these savings, she will be able to support her family's needs and build her own home.  She is a member of the community group "Rima."

loans.use: To increase the business' capital for the expansion of the restaurant by purchasing large quantities of food items to sell to its clients

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is 38 years old and married to M. J. who operates a sweetmeat selling business. He operates his shop in the market and is well known for his good quality sweetmeat. Razia is a housewife who stays at home and does her housework. She takes her responsibilities very seriously and makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family. She is the mother of a son and two daughters. All of them study by attending a local school. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy required ingredients like milk, sugar, cooking oil and dry fruits etc to make good quantity sweetmeat. This will help him sell more and earn a better profit. 
Razia hopes that after this investment, her husband’s business will be in a more profitable position and it will result in a better financial condition for her family. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fourth loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. She lives in Mian Channu, which is a small city in Punjab Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Muhallah Rehmania for the past 10 years with her family in a two-room brick house.

loans.use: To buy required ingredients for making sweetmeats

loans.name: Rufa

texts.en:
Rufa S. is from the village of Tipolohon, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is a 41-year-old married woman with two school-aged children. To make a living, Rufa owns and operates a business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income comes from buying and selling vegetables like onions and spices within the local community. Rufa has been involved in this business for over three years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rufa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rufa successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. The previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Rufa is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Rufa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard S. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 39 years old. Richard is single. To make a living, Richard owns & operates a business venture in the transportation sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motorcycle transport in the local community. Richard has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Richard joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Richard has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair the existing vehicle for better service. Richard is requesting a new loan of 16000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Richard from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

location.town: Brgy. Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Lady-Lyn

texts.en:
Lady-lyn F. is from the village of Brgy. Bone North, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 21 years old. Lady-lyn is single. To make a living, Lady-lyn owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing party services to local community members. She provides chairs and tables and video oke for rent. Lady-lyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Lady-lyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lady-lyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional chairs and tables for better rental services. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Lady-lyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional chairs and tables to provide better service

location.town: Brgy. Bone North, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Vukuzame Group

texts.en:
Nikeziwe  is 44 years old and married  with 3 children, between 15 and 23 years. She cares  for one relative. She runs a retail business in Nkandla in Kwa Zulu Natal, South Africa. In the photo above she is standing on the far left

She's been in this business for 1 year and sells chips and drinks at her home.  She says that the main challenges to her business are customers who buy on credit and fail to pay on time.

She requested this loan through Women’s Development Businesses to buy drinks. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her send her children to a higher education institution and will help her have more stock to make a profit. In the future, she hopes to see her business grow, and end up having a spazza shop ( spazza shops are small corner stores where you can buy food, drink and other basics).

In her comments she adds that WDB has helped her a lot and they must continue helping others

loans.use: To buy drinks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a scanner and a CO testing and regulating machine

loans.name: Andriy

texts.en:
Andriy is married with two sons. He lives in Ivano-Frankivsk along with his family. Andriy runs a clothing sales business, selling men’s and women’s underwear, socks, pantyhose, pajamas, etc. He owns a vending facility at the central marketplace of his home town. Andriy’s business has been around for 12 years. Currently, his monthly profit amounts to 6,000 Grivnyas. 

Andriy is requesting a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas. He believes the current loan will help him purchase additional stock and offer a better selection of spring and summer merchandise to his customers. Andriy is planning to use the loan to purchase men’s and children’s underwear. Andriy likes his job. He remembers times when he had to work at a local factory and his salary was never sufficient for his family needs, or other times when he was a freelancer trying to find work in construction.  He never knew if he would have the money to feed his family the next day. Andriy is hoping to continue growing his business, using the profits to finish building his private house where his family lives at the moment.

loans.use: To purchase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Concepceon

texts.en:
Concepceon A. is from the village of Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Concepceon is separated from her spouse and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Concepceon owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling snack foods, canned goods & beverages. She also buys and raises pigs for sale.  Concepceon has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Concepceon joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Concepceon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Concepceon is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods & snack foods. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Concepceon from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Uranbileg

texts.en:
Uranbileg is 43 years old and lives with her husband, son, daughter, son-in-law and granddaughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house, in the outer ger districts of the city. Her son attends college, while her husband works as a driver at a local company. Uranbileg worked as a teacher at a kindergarten from 1989 to 2000.

Uranbileg supports her family by operating two clothing retail stalls at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia, with regular help from her daughter and daughter’s husband. 

Uranbileg began her business in 2000 and now she has 2,500,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) in working capital at her two stalls. She purchases clothing for her business from China once or twice a month, depending on her income. She is requesting a 800,000 MNT to purchase clothing for spring from Ereen City, China. She wants to use this loan to help support her in this very busy shopping season of the year.  

Her business goal is to improve her business by buying her own indoor clothing store. This will be more comfortable than working outside everyday at Narantuul market.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for spring

loans.name: Umi

texts.en:
Umi is a 51-year-old widow. She has 3 sons who are still single. They are: Arif, 28 years; Rohman, 25 years old; and Wahyu, 23 years old.

Umi has a food stall business which has been running since 1991. She sells foods such as rice, vegetables and side dishes, fried bananas, fried sweet potatoes and beverages. After running the business for almost 20 years, her food stall has never been renovated, so it is unattractive. Her business place seems no longer appropriate for use.

From everyday sales she can generate profit about IDR 45,000 to 60.000.  She keeps half of the profit to pay the rental fee of her food stall of IDR 2 million per year and the rental fee of her house, IDR 3 million per year. She spends the remaining profit on daily needs. Umi feels that the profit is still small and sometimes she needs the support of her children.

Umi wishes to add more types of foods to sell at her food stall. She is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 3,000,000. She is very excited to imagine that the loan would enable her to renovate her food stall be more attractive and improve her business by selling more foods.

loans.use: To renovate the food stall and sell more foods

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine R. is from the village of Olingan. She is 54 years old, is widowed, and has two adult children and one school-aged child.

Josephine owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase feed for her pigs.

Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fresh fish to sell. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fish to sell

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a 57-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a furniture business. She lives in Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her furniture business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000. Evelyn is borrowing PHP 25,000 to fund operations. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Evelyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Lala

texts.fr:
Madame Lala T. est une femme mariée de quarante deux ans avec deux enfants vivant dans une famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanankoroba située à 35  kilomètres de Bamako.
Après les études, elle intégra le programme de prêt de groupe de Soro Yiriwaso il y a de cela sept ans dans le but de bien mener son activité génératrice de revenus qu’est la restauration. Tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés et elle est à son quatrième prêt individuel destiné à la constitution de stocks de condiments alimentaires et de denrées alimentaires pour la restauration. Elle s’approvisionne une fois par semaine à Bamako et compte avoir avec ce prêt, 60  kilogrammes de condiments, une tonne de  diverses céréales  et des tubercules. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75.000  FCFA  pour rembourser les échéances du prêt et investir dans ses affaires.
Elle compte toujours sur l’appui financier de Soro Yiriwaso pour l’ouverture de nouvel restaurant en d’autre localité où le besoin se pose.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lala T. is a 42-year old married woman with two children, and she lives in a traditional extended family in Sanankoroba, located 35 kilometers from Bamako.

After she finished school, she became part of the Soro Yiriwaso's group loan program seven years ago. She was seeking to improve her restaurant business. All of her previous loans have been fully repaid, and she is on her fourth individual loan, which will be used to create a stock of condiments and food products. She gets her supplies once a week in Bamako. With this loan, she plans to buy sixty kilograms of condiments and one ton of various cereals and root vegetables.

She hopes to make an average monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA to make loan payments and invest in her business. She also hopes to use Soro Yiriwaso's financing to open new restaurants in other locations where they are needed.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for restaurant

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen is a widow who lives in Sta. Catalina, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating a fishing/fish vending business. She has six children who are between 12 and 27 years old. Carmen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Carmen has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to purchase fishing equipment so that she can continue to save up for her children’s future education. Carmen is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment

loans.name: Bambang
loans.use: To buy new spare parts

loans.name: Mamoutou

texts.fr:
Monsieur MAMOUTOU M. est marié, âgé de trente trois ans et père de deux enfants. Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec sa femme et ses enfants à SANANKOROBA situé à 35  kilomètres de Bamako (capitale du Mali). 
Après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans réussite, il décida d’intégrer le système crédit  de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son premier prêt individuel .
Il compte acheter, 10 sacs de sucre, 5 cartons de thé et d’autres produits à Bamako qu’il stockera chez lui, avant de les  vendre dans sa boutique, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et des femmes résidant à Sanankoroba et environnants. Il mène cette activité durant toute l’année et s’approvisionne deux fois par mois.
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice de 45.000  F CFA par mois qu’il utilisera pour les dépenses de la famille et investir dans son activité de vente de boutique.
texts.en: Mr. MAMOUTOU M. is married, 33 years old, and father of two children.  He lives in a monogamous family with his wife and children in SANANKOROBA, located 35 kilometers from Bamako (the capital of Mali).  After pursuing many businesses without success, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, where he has his first individual loan.  He intends to buy 10 bags of sugar, 5 cartons of tea, and other products in Bamako, which he will store at his home, before selling them in his shop to male and female customers that live in and around Sanakoroba.  He runs this business throughout the year and stocks up twice per month. He hopes to make a profit of 45,000 FCFA per month, which he will use for family expenses and invest in his retail business.

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is a widow. She lost her husband due to a car accident. Natalya was forced to find ways to support herself and her newborn baby. The tragedy didn’t break her. She found the strength to move on and even started her own clothing sales business. She launched her trade 10 years ago. Presently, Natalya has two vending locations. Her gross income amounts to 24,000 Grivnyas. Net profit is over 4,000 Grivnyas a month. 

Natalya is seeking a loan of 20,000 Grivnyas to purchase seasonal merchandise. She is planning to purchase women’s spring clothing items, i.e. jackets, blouses, pants, etc. and diversify assorted merchandise she offers for sale. The business has helped Natalya take her mind off painful memories of the past and look into the future with hope. She is seeking to keep her business running and profitable as it the only way to provide for herself and her child and guarantee a secure future for their family.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Nataline

texts.en: Nataline is a 28-year-old married woman living and working with her husband in Tayouneh. Nataline has worked as a beauty expert since 2003. She works with her husband at the same salon. He is a hairdresser, while she's specialized in makeup, tattoos and nail polish. She also gives beauty therapies and advice. Nataline states that a woman must prove herself and must work hard to achieve her goals. She also believes that these days the woman must help her husband with their income, since everything is so expensive these days. In order to improve her part of the salon, Nataline is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua, to redecorate, which is necessary to attract old and new clients from Nataline's point of view. She is sure that the client must see a change in the atmosphere, which psychologically reflects positively on him.

loans.use: To do necessary decoration for her salon

loans.name: Bibiana

texts.en:
Bibiana C. is from the village of Sta. Filomena. She is 59 years old, married, and has nine adult-aged children.

Bibiana owns and operates a business raising pigs in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Bibiana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase materials for the renovation of her pig fence.

Bibiana is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase piglets and feed. This loan will be her fourth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou L. is from the village of Olingan. She is 30 years old, married, and has 6 school aged children. Marilou operates a motorcycle in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marilou joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for motorcycle registration. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase spare parts for motorcycle repair. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marilou from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for motorcycle repair.

loans.name: Roxanne

texts.en:
Roxanne is a married woman who lives in Daanbantayan, Cebu. She earns her living buying and selling dry goods.  Her husband Elmer, who is 35 years old, works as a vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are 7 to 17 years old. Roxanne joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past six loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Roxanne has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 7th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use to pay for more stocks for her business so that she can continue to save up for future education and expansion of her business. Roxanne is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Shazia's Group

texts.en:
Shazia is married to M. A. who has a business of selling vegetables. He puts vegetables on his four-wheeled cart in the morning and visits different streets of the city to sell them. He is very good person and treats his clients respectfully. Shazia is a housewife and prefers to stay at home and do her household tasks. She is a very supportive lady, always ready to help her family at difficult times. She has given birth to 2 daughters and 3 sons. All of them are studying by attending the local school. 

Shazia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her husband’s vegetable selling business. With the loan, he will buy fresh seasonal vegetables for selling. He has been operating this business for the past 15 years and Shazia is hopeful that an investment will help him increase his sales and profits. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. In her previous loan years, she has always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. She is a resident of Mian channu, which is a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan,  known for its agriculture industry.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal vegetables for selling.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is a mother of 5 children who are between the ages of 14 and 6 years old. Florence sells lumber for house construction. She works with her husband. Florence is requesting a loan in order to buy more lumber. She plans to reinvest in her business with the profits that she hopes to make.

loans.use: Buying lumber.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI est un regroupement de 6 femmes ayant en moyenne trente cinq ans, six enfants et vivant  dans des familles nucléaires à la Mission, un des quartiers de la ville de OUELESSEBOUGOU (2ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce du beurre de karité, de savons, du charbon de bois avec ALIMATOU S., des pagnes wax, etc.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt,  40 sacs de charbons. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché  de OUELESSEBOUGOU et marchés environants  auprès des grossistes. Ellle effectue sa vente au  marché de Ouelessebougou, BAMAKO et à domicile à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, en détail, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en: BENKADI is a group of 6 women who are, on average, thirty-five years old with six children and live in nuclear families in the Mission, a district of the city of Ouelessebougou (2nd administrative region of Mali).  This is their first loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with the goal is of satisfying the needs of their customers.  This group of women sell charcoal with Alimatou S. as well as shea butter, soap, wax pagnes (colorful African cloth) etc. Alimatou S. plans to buy 40 bags of charcoal with the loan. She gets her supplies from wholesalers at the OUELESSEBOUGOU Grand Market and surrounding markets. She sells her goods retail, in cash or on credit, at the Ouelessebougou, BAMAKO market and at her home to a largely female clientele. She hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 30,000 CFA of which a part will be used to help her husband with everyday expenses and the remainder will be invested in the businesses.

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Algrace

texts.en:
Algrace is a 29-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: tricycle transport, pig fattening and networking (Natasha & Avon).  She lives in Danao City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2010 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,800. Algrace is borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her business. This will be her third loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Algrace aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To fund the operations of her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria P., a 64-year-old married woman with nine adult children, is from the village of Olingan. She owns and operates a business in the retail sector. The main source of income from the business comes from selling candles to the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month.

In 2005, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria has fully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Maria is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase candle wax for her candle making business. This loan will be her 9th from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase candle wax for candle making.

loans.name: Valerie

texts.en: Valerie is 36 years old and she has 6 children. The eldest is 15 years while the youngest is 5 months. Valerie adopted 3 of the children. Valerie sells locally made beer, which is made out of sorghum. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more sorghum and hence make more profits. With the profits Valerie plans to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: Buying sorghum.

loans.name: Amparo

texts.en:
Amparo is a married woman who lives in Calatrava, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  a sari-sari (general) store and a sugarcane field. Her husband Celso, who is 65 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have 10 children who are between between 18 and 42 years old. Amparo joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1993 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 19 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Amparo has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 1,300, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 20th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use as funds for business operations so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Amparo is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joiniung the Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva,org.

loans.use: To fund her business operations

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena V. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 36 years old, is married, and has 3 school-aged children.

Rowena owns and operates a business in the retail sector, primarily operating a general store. She has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP.

In 2006, Rowena joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC.

Rowena is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store. This loan will be her 5th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en: Vestine is 40 years old and has 7 children, who are between the ages of 2 and 17 years old. Vestine has a restaurant, and she is requesting a loan to purchase food stuffs, such as Irish potatoes, sodas, and fresh milk. With the profits, she plans to renovate her house.

loans.use: Purchase food stuffs.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson is 29 years old and married with three children whose ages range from five months to ten years. Benson has been in the farming business for five years and sells his milk and eggs to the local market. 

He has requested a loan of 31,200Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to improve his family's standard of living. His biggest challenge has been diseases that affect his dairy farming. He plans to acquire two more dairy cows and a motorcycle in the next five years.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie F. is from the village of Disud. She is 44 years old. Rosemarie is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Rosemarie operates a business venture selling different products, such as clothes and other ready-to-wear products. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rosemarie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to add to her capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Rosemarie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI est un groupe de l’association SIGUIDIYA du FILABOUGOU de Ouelessebougou. Il regroupe 4 femmes qui se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans. Constitué de mariées et veuve ayant au moins deux enfants, ce groupe de femmes mènent différentes activités  telles l’achat vente d’habits et de légumes à l’image de MARIAM D.. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles à Ouelessebougou dans la préfecture de Kati (Région de Koulikoro, République du Mali). 
Elles sont dans le petit commerce depuis plusieurs années et sont très sollicitées dans leurs activités. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin croissant de leur clientèle, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel, elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire. 
MARIAM D., qui est la présidente du groupe et très connue à Ouelessebougou, excelle dans l’achat vente de légumes. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, plusieurs paniers de légumes de différentes sortes (poivre, tomate, oignon, choux, etc.).  Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako auprès des grossistes  et vend ses articles à Ouelessebougou et dans les différentes foires hebdomadaires, en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.   
Elle espère sur un bénéfice mensuel de 25.000FCFA somme qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans son activité.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of the Siguidiya Association in the Filabougou neighborhood of Ouelessebougou. It brings together four women who know one another through family and neighborhood ties. They have an average age of 30 years. Made up of married women and widows with at least two children, this group of women heads different businesses, such as the purchase of clothing and vegetables, like Mariam D.. They live in large traditional families in Ouelessebougou in the prefecture of Kati (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

These women have been running their small businesses for several years and their services are highly sought-after.

In the hope of meeting the growing demand of their customers, the members of the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, with which they're taking their first group loan.

Mariam D., who is the group's president and very well-known in Ouelessebougou, excels in the purchase and sale of vegetables. She plans to use her loan to buy several baskets of different types of vegetables (pepper, tomato, onion, cabbage, etc.). She supplies her business from wholesalers in Bamako and sells her goods retail in Ouelessebougou and at the various weekly markets, for cash and credit, to a customer base made up mostly of women.

She hopes to make a monthly profit of 25,000 CFA francs, a figure that will allow her to repay the loan and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables.

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en: Claudine is 47 years old and she has 4 children who are between the ages 16 to 21 years. Three of her children are in school and one has already completed school. Claudine sells plastic products, such as jerrycans (jugs used for transporting liquids). Claudine is requesting a loan in order to buy more plastic products in order to make more profits.

loans.use: Purchasing more plastic products.

loans.name: Kankele Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 femmes du groupe KANKELE ont en moyenne quarante ans, cinq enfants et vivent  dans des  familles nucléaires à Ouelessebougou ville, préfecture de Kati, relevant de Koulikoro (2ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de cosmétiques, de  gingembre, d’encens, de condiments alimentaires, d’habits à l’image de KADIA K., etc.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, trente kilogrammes de gingembre et quinze  chargements de charrettes  en  bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché  de SIKASSO et dans les villages environnants de Ouelessebougou et  effectue sa vente au  marché de Ouelessebougou et domicile  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, en détail, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women of the group KANKELE have an average age of forty years, five children and live in nuclear families in the city of Ouelessebougou, district of  Kati, in the region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of Mali).
